summary.seg: This manuscript is a pastoral and devotional work compiled from quotations of the church fathers and the Yorkshire religious writers de Burgo, John, -1398 John de Burgo (d. after 1398) and Rolle, Richard Richard Rolle, 1300-1349 (ca. 1300–30 September 1349). The author or authors is unknown, but it is believed to have been composed in the 1390s.

Cibus anime was perhaps intended as a pastoral handbook for parish priests to refer to, for example, when deciding on suitable penance for confessed sins. The manuscript concerns the Articles of Faith, the Ten Commandments, the corporal and spiritual Works of Mercy, and the seven deadly sins and cardinal virtues. It is divided into two books: Book 1 contains 52 chapters and, book 2 has 62 chapters. It is mostly written in Latin, but is interspersed with lines of Middle English (fols. 88b, 92b, 94)

This work is associated with York Minster and was originally circulated only in Yorkshire among the clergy. The colophon contains a request for prayers for the souls of Robert, Thomas and Henry Garton, ( fol. 91v ) who were members of an East Riding clerical family.
This manuscript was given to the College by Robert Hare (d. 1611).

collation.p: a2 (+1)stuck to cover 1 8)- 118, -124 (+1) b2 2 stuck to cover.

decoNote.p: Initials with blue and red pen flourishing and infill in both colours throughout.
One illustration showing two ladders: Heaven and Hell (fol. 92)

binding.p: Blue morocco leather of c18th century over the old boards, marks of 2 clasps traceable. Inside the cover is pasted a remarkable label, once no doubt on the outside. It is inscribed in large letters, the first in red, the rest in gold on a flourished ground, Cibus anime.
In the cover are two leaves of a 14th century law treatise beginning:
Cum humani iuris condicio semper in in… decurrat.

provenance.p: Belonged to Hare, Robert Robert Hare , whose name is at each end.

recordHist.source: Description draws on James, M. R. (1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall.

listBibl.bibl: Gillespie, Vincent. (1983) ‘The cibus anime book 3: a guide for contemplatives’, Analecta Cartusiana: Review for Carthusian History and Spirituality 35, pp. 90-119.
Gillespie, Vincent. (1989) ‘The evolution of the Speculum Christiani’, in A.J. Minnis, editor, Latin and Vernacular Studies in Late-Medieval Texts and Manuscripts, Cambridge, pp. 39-62.

Hughes, Jonathan, ‘The Administration of Confession in the Diocese of York’ in Studies in Clergy and Ministry in Medieval England, ed. Smith, David M. (1991). Borthwick Institute Publications, pp. 87-163
James, M. R. (1907). A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity Hall. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp 33-34.
